entry.title: Unleashing the Power of ASTER: Scripting Your Way to Enhanced SAP Integration Testing
entry.content:
What is ASTER?

ASTER stands for "Another Syntax Tree Expression Runtime." But what does that really mean? Essentially, ASTER is a scripting language that allows you to go beyond standard configuration-based data manipulation and validation within Int4 Suite. It provides a syntax tree execution runtime, enabling you to handle complex scenarios and edge cases with greater ease and efficiency.

Think of it this way: while Int4 Suite's configuration-based engine is incredibly robust and serves the majority of testing needs brilliantly, ASTER offers an additional layer of flexibility for those unique, intricate situations. It's not meant to replace the existing, proven methods but rather to enhance them, providing you with a powerful tool for advanced features.

Why ASTER? The Story Behind the Script

Int4 Suite has a well-deserved reputation for its strong configuration-based data manipulation and validation engine. It has been instrumental in supporting large-scale cloud integration migrations. However, as with any powerful tool, there are always scenarios that push the boundaries.

We began to notice recurring questions and challenges from our users, particularly around variable manipulation and complex validations. "Is it possible to concatenate variables?" "How can we handle this specific edge case?" These questions spurred us to think beyond the existing configuration options.

The turning point came with a particularly demanding validation scenario presented by a customer. It became clear that we needed a solution that could enable more than just what configuration alone could provide. That's when the idea for ASTER began to take shape. What started as a small concept evolved into a significant addition to the Int4 Suite, designed to empower users with the ability to script their own solutions.

The Technology Behind ASTER

ASTER is built on a solid foundation of ABAP classes. The parsing and execution of the ASTER script occur in a safe and isolated environment, ensuring that your scripting activities don't interfere with the underlying ABAP server environment. This isolation means you can confidently use ASTER without worrying about unintended side effects.

Key Features of ASTER

  • Syntax Tree Execution: ASTER utilizes a syntax tree approach, which is a common technique in language design. This allows for efficient parsing and evaluation of expressions, even complex ones.
  • Dynamic Typing: ASTER is dynamically typed, meaning you don't have to worry about declaring data types. This simplifies scripting and makes it more accessible.
  • Arithmetic and String Manipulation: ASTER supports basic arithmetic operations, string manipulation, and boolean logic, providing you with the tools you need for a wide range of tasks.
  • User-Defined Functions: You can build your own functions in ASTER, allowing you to create reusable code and tailor the language to your specific needs.
  • Integration with Int4 Suite: ASTER seamlessly integrates with Int4 Suite features. You can access test case execution data, payloads, set variables, and more, making it a powerful tool for enhancing your testing workflows.
  • Safe and Isolated Environment: ASTER scripts are executed in a safe and isolated environment, ensuring that they don't interfere with the underlying ABAP server.


Getting Started with ASTER

ASTER is designed to be intuitive and easy to learn, especially if you have some familiarity with other programming languages. We've drawn inspiration from popular languages to make the syntax familiar and accessible.


Where to Play with ASTER

In the upcoming Int4 Suite 3.11 release, you'll find a new tile called "Scripts" within the Int4 tiles. This tile will provide access to a script management interface and a user-friendly editor. The editor, based on the open-source Ace editor, has been extended to support ASTER syntax, including syntax highlighting and code completion. This makes writing and debugging ASTER scripts a breeze.

Basic Concepts

  • Expressions: ASTER primarily works with expressions. An expression is a piece of code that evaluates to a value. This could be a simple arithmetic calculation, a string, or a more complex operation.
  • Variables: You can use variables in ASTER to store and manipulate data. Variables don't need to be explicitly declared; you can simply assign a value to a variable and start using it.
  • Semicolons: Use semicolons to separate multiple expressions on a single line.
  • Output: The output of an ASTER script is the result of the last evaluated expression.

Example: Hello World

Here's a simple "Hello World" example in ASTER:

"Hello World";

When you run this script, the output will be "Hello World."

Beyond Hello World

Of course, ASTER can do much more than just print "Hello World." You can perform arithmetic calculations, manipulate strings, work with variables, and build complex logic as shown in Figure below.

Extending Int4 Suite with ASTER

One of the most exciting aspects of ASTER is its ability to extend the capabilities of Int4 Suite. You can use ASTER to:

  • Perform complex data validations: Validate data based on calculations, comparisons, and logical operations.
  • Manipulate data: Transform and manipulate data in ways that are not possible with standard configuration.

  • Handle edge cases: Address unique and intricate scenarios that require custom logic.
  • Automate tasks: Automate repetitive tasks and streamline your testing workflows.

Using the Aster script is done directly in the payload processing tab of Automation Objects as shown in the Figure below.

The Future of ASTER

We believe that ASTER has the potential to revolutionize how you approach integration testing with Int4 Suite. We're committed to continuously improving ASTER and adding new features based on your feedback.

Kudos

Special Kudos to our two members of our Int4 Suite Product Team - Marcin Galczynski and Tomasz Mackowski for making ASTER happen!  

Conclusion

ASTER is a powerful new scripting language that brings enhanced flexibility and precision to integration testing with Int4 Suite. It allows you to handle complex scenarios, manipulate data, and automate tasks with greater ease. We encourage you to explore ASTER and discover the possibilities it unlocks for your testing workflows.

Stay tuned for the release of Int4 Suite 3.11 and get ready to unleash the power of ASTER!
I hope this blog post meets your needs! Let me know if you'd like any adjustments or further assistance.

entry.title: Agentic Testing and Simulation with Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph
entry.content:
Intro 

Have you ever wondered why simulation and test automation software is not accessible in a easy way to everyone for SAP projects? Now with Agentic Testing and Simulation based on Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph it's no longer the case with Int4 Suite. You can use your enterprise AI and to simulate any 3rd party test system and run any automated SAP Business process test defined in Int4 Suite.

Why use Agents and AI for Testing and Simulation of SAP applications?

The Int4 Suite stores millions of historical electronic messages (test cases) pulled from various integration platforms and SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC backends using Int4 Suite Robotic Crawler, as shown in the figure below.

These messages can be grouped into folders and executed across development and test environments. However, this traditional approach comes with two major challenges:

a) Finding the Right Test Cases - Even with our powerful Test Case Analyzer, searching through millions of test messages can be overwhelming. Imagine needing to find all messages related to incoming sales orders for:

Customer: 5002334

Materials: T-DK0001 and B-234234

Even with perfectly structured folders, locating the right data might still take several minutes. Multiply that effort across teams and use cases, it adds up.

b) Accessibility and Democratization of Testing - At Int4, we champion citizen testing. Testing and simulation shouldnâ€™t be limited to users with automation expertise. Anyone should be able to run tests, manual or automated, easily and intuitively. Thatâ€™s why Int4 Suite isnâ€™t licensed by the number of users. We believe in unrestricted access for all who need to test SAP-integrated business processes.

How Agentic Testing and Simulation Solves These Challenges?

With Agentic Testing and Simulation built on Int4 Suiteâ€™s SAP Business Knowledge Graph, we can either eliminate or significantly reduce the two main pain points above:

a) Smarter Test Case Discovery - by combining:

  • Historical messages,

  • Master data,

  • And entity relationships,

our intelligent agents enable users to perform semantic and business-context-based searches across all test cases. You can now search using natural language or business-specific criteria and execute relevant tests instantly similarly as shown in Figure below. 

b) AI-Driven Chat for Testing - thanks to enterprise AI and chat-based interfaces, anyone, from any SAP S/4HANA or SAP BTP project, can now access and use testing features without needing to understand the underlying software mechanics.

This brings simulation and automated testing closer to business analysts, project managers, and functional consultants, not just developers or testers.

Why Int4 Suiteâ€™s SAP Business Knowledge Graph is a Game Changer?

Having access to millions of test messages is powerful. But being able to query those test cases from a business perspective makes it revolutionary.

Instead of filtering only by material numbers or quantities, imagine asking:

  • Pharmaceutical industry:
    "Show me test cases of sales orders containing materials flagged as high-risk."

  • FMCG industry:
    "Find sales orders from partners where deliveries were most delayed in the last 3â€“6 monthsâ€”especially when it led to lost priority unloading slots."

To enable these kinds of queries, the Business Knowledge Graph links test data with master data and maps relationships between themâ€”unlocking far more intuitive, business-relevant insights.

Where to Learn More About Int4 Suite?

ðŸ‘‰Visit our SAP Learning Course - Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

entry.title: New Mass-Upload of Test Cases in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
New Mass-Upload of Test Cases in SAP Cloud ALM

It is now possible to upload a large number of test cases to SAP Cloud ALM using the mass upload feature.
With this blog post I briefly describe the process.

1. Click on the Test Preparation app

2. Navigate to the "Upload Button"

3. Download the template to fill it with your test cases

4. Perform the upload

Ideas and input for SAP

  • What would certainly be helpful is downloading existing test cases in SAP Cloud ALM, editing them in Excel, and uploading them again.
  • The exchange and reuse of test cases between multiple SAP Cloud ALM projects would also be helpful.
  • SAP should also consider the easy storage of test cases from multiple projects into a central operational project. This is a requirement I hear from many customers.

Conclusion

In any case, the new mass upload of test cases is a very helpful feature and a first big step in the right direction.

It saves us a lot of time and makes test management much more efficient.

Thank you SAP for providing this functionality.

entry.title: Project Kernseife - improving the measurement of Clean Core in ABAP
entry.content:
TL;DR

To improve the handling and measuring of classic ABAP code in ATC with regards to clean core, the possibility of an ATC check based on a custom classification was developed and is now published as an open source project named "Project Kernseife".

 

Challenges in Measuring Clean Core

Working in the area of clean core - especially focusing on the dimension "extensibility" - in projects of different scales, we were more than once asked in the last years on how to measure and govern the clean core principles within SAP S/4HANA systems (focusing on Private Cloud & On-Premises).

A key part to describe the "clean core state" of extensions is from our point of view the creation of a technical debt score that should align with the governance process in your system. That is why SAP's own code quality tool ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) is very helpful on this. Since the release of "ABAP Cloud" as target for On-Stack extensions, we have now possibibilities with the related ATC Check Variant (ABAP_CLOUD_READINESS) to identify the "distance to Tier 1".

But looking at landscapes with large amount of legacy code (e.g. > 100,000 custom code objects in classic ABAP) or systems where you cannot use sufficiently released APIs for Tier 1, it becomes more difficult to identify the "real" technical debt.

If you run with the default ABAP_CLOUD_READINESS variant into larger systems, you might be overwhelmed by a huge number of findings in ATC - that are all marked as Error. This is logical, if you want to identify the criticality as "what do I need to change to get into ABAP Cloud", but at the same time the important technical debt might be hidden behind a lot of "false positive" findings.

To improve this situation, SAP released the new Clean Core check (SAP Note 3565942) in February of 2025, with the addition of Clean Core Levels in August 2025. This check improves the situation by analyzing "classic" coding with a stronger focus on technical debt, to identify the "right" things. It is based on SAP's released objects (Filter on "State": "Released"; Level A, official APIs) and nominated Classic APIs (Filter on "State": "classic API"; Level B). These Classic APIs belong either to business logic (e.g. BAPI_PO_CREATE1) or a technical framework (e.g. ALV). Finally, there are now also "noAPIs" (objects that must not be used, e.g. RFC_READ_TABLE) nominated by SAP (Filter on "State": "No API"; Level D).

Still - we saw a gap in projects to improve the lifes of lead developers: A custom classification. Because SAP may not be able to classify a certain ABAP object as precise as you may be able to do. So SAP is not publishing any information on a given ABAP object and it is shown as accessing an internal object (which leads in ATC to a warning). But in your use case, you are fine with using it. And this is where Kernseife can help you.

 

What is "Kernseife"?

Kernseife consists of two parts:

  1. A custom ATC Check that is based on the new Clean Core check mentioned above, but uses a custom classification system.
  2. CAP Application to create a custom classification of ABAP objects (and we even use it to analyze results from systems in a simple way).

ATC Check for custom classification

As mentioned, we started to work on "Kernseife" in 2024 as there was no detailed Clean Core check available then. Therefore, our focus was initially to create a custom ATC check that can work with a custom classification. It is now re-worked and based on the "new" ATC Check (Note 3565942).

This check is basically analyzing your custom code like the Clean Core check, but when it comes to the evaluation of the impact of a finding, the custom classification comes into play. You can upload the custom classification as a JSON file and in this classification will then used to determine your findings. Let's explain the difference with an example:

In your project, you need to work with the RF framework, because you are implementing EWM in your Private Cloud Environment. Therefore, you need to work with the classes /SCWM/CL_RF*, that are the recommended way to interact with the RF framework. If you look into the Cloudifcation Repostory, you can see that these classes are not "released" or nominated as "classic API ". Still, you want to generally accept the usage of the RF framework for both: Governance of developers (ATC Checks) and measuring your "distance to clean core".

By using your custom classification which contains the classes /SCWM/CL_RF* as "Business Function - Recommended" (BF1), which will lead to only "Information" (Prio 3) findings in the check and will have a lower impact on the "clean core score", you can improve your efficiency.

For details on the custom classification, you can check the classification guide.

Application to manage Classifications

Of course, you could maintain the JSON file of the classification manually based on the given json format. But we created a little app, that is currently in a feature branch, to do that in a more sophisticated way.

In this application, you can initially check the current state for objects as defined by SAP and additionally add objects that are not yet mentioned by SAP.

Sticking with the example from above, you can now edit the "Rating Code" of the /SCWM/CL_RF* classes to "BF1". After you did your changes, you can download the classification JSON file, upload it into your ATC check system and all of the findings for these classes will in future be recorded as "Information" (Prio 3) message.

 

Governance and Measurability

With this custom classification and the usage in ABAP Test Cockpit, we can now combine the governance view and the measurability within ATC.

Governance

By enhancing SAP's default rating, you can control your developers more efficiently. Because as of today, your lead developers that are able to approve exemptions might be overwhelmed by a lot of "false positive" ATC findings. Just imagine every usage of the example classes "/SCWM/CL_RF*" need to be exempted.

In projects - especially looking at the overwhelming errors from the "ABAP_CLOUD_READINESS" ATC check in classic ABAP, you can now control with your custom classification, that recurring "false positive" findings will disappear (or become prio 3 messages only).

This is important, as - being a reviewer - your chances to ask questions on the important findings will improve. Because if for every major developments you need to approve hundreds of exemption requests, you will most probably go into "autopilot" approval mode as you cannot check all of the requests in detail.

Measurability

Our second motivation to create this check is to create a more realistic impact rating to measure what we call the "Kernseife Score" (basically: a technical debt score per object). With every classification (BF1), we consider a score of how severe the impact of using this SAP object is with regards to clean core.

So you can configure now a score - we did use a 0 to 10 scale - to identify how severe is a single finding. Based on the ATC check, we can now provide per object a score that you can use for your reporting. Either to identify the total score per system, per package, per object - or even to deep dive into analyses like "which object has the worst average score per finding?" or "which object is in total view the "uncleanest" object in my system?".

While you can then easily use your analytics tools (e.g. SAP Analytics Cloud) to create the dashboards you need, in our repository you can at least find a CDS-View you can use for extraction (ZKNSF_I_SCORING), that combines the findings with the score. If you want to directly extract e.g. a list aggregated by object, you could directly use another CDS-View (ZKNSF_I_DEVELOPMENT_OBJECTS).

 

What's next?

Kernseife is currently in use (or in prior versions) in several projects. But to be very clear: There is development ongoing, but we do not have a product roadmap available.

But as it is open source, we are open to feature discussions or pull requests - or just use it for your own advantage!

entry.title: Retrieve Data from Rest API to ABAP
entry.content:
Introduction

In abap, we create and expose API service through the OData gateway client for integration with third-party systems. This blog focuses on how to retrieve data from a REST API using a standard ABAP class. I have created the OData service using the GET_ENTITY method in an OData project and consumed that API using the approach described below.

  • cl_http_client
  • if_http_client
****Data Declarations****
TYPES: BEGIN OF tt_json,
         MaterialCode TYPE matnr,           "Material
         UserName     TYPE ernam,           "Creator Name
         mtart        TYPE mtart,           "Material Type
       END OF tt_json.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_field,
         fielname TYPE char40,              "Field Name
       END OF ty_field.

DATA: lt_material     TYPE TABLE OF tt_json,
      lt_tab          TYPE TABLE OF ty_field,
      ls_material     TYPE tt_json,
      lo_http         TYPE REF TO if_http_client,    "HTTP Client Abstraction
      lr_data         TYPE REF TO data,
      lv_result       TYPE string,
      lv_content_type TYPE string,
      lv_action_type  TYPE string.

FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_data>   TYPE data,
               <ls_d>      TYPE data,
               <ls_struct> TYPE data,
               <lv_any>    TYPE any,
               <lv_char>.

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK a1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-002.
  PARAMETERS: p_mat TYPE matnr OBLIGATORY.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK a1.

*Get URL
DATA(lv_url) =  |{ TEXT-001 }'{ p_mat }')|  .

The API and selection screen look likes,

 

 

"To perform the HTTP communication using factory method.
cl_http_client=>create_by_url(
  EXPORTING
    url                    = lv_url           " URL
  IMPORTING
    client                 = lo_http          " HTTP Client Abstraction
  EXCEPTIONS
    argument_not_found     = 1                " Communication parameter (host or service) not available
    plugin_not_active      = 2                " HTTP/HTTPS communication not available
    internal_error         = 3                " Internal error (e.g. name too long)
    OTHERS                 = 7
).
"
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  lv_content_type  = 'application/json'.
  lv_action_type   = 'GET'.
  lo_http->request->set_content_type(  lv_content_type ).
  lo_http->request->set_method( lv_action_type ).
"The output shows a json format.
  lo_http->request->set_header_field(
  EXPORTING
    name  =  'Accept'                          " Name of the header field
    value =  'application/json'                " HTTP header field value
).
"To ignore the authentication during execution.
  lo_http->propertytype_logon_popup = if_http_client=>co_disabled.
  lo_http->authenticate(
  EXPORTING
    proxy_authentication = ' '            " Proxy Logon (= 'X')
    client               = '800'          " R/3 system (client number from logon)
    username             = 'username'     " ABAP System, User Logon Name
    password             = 'password'     " Logon ID
    language             = 'E'            " SAP System, Current Language
).
ENDIF.

lo_http->send(
  EXPORTING
    timeout                    = 15                 " Timeout of Answer Waiting Time
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1                  " Communication Error
    http_invalid_state         = 2                  " Invalid state
    http_processing_failed     = 3                  " Error when processing method
    http_invalid_timeout       = 4                  " Invalid Time Entry
    OTHERS                     = 5
).
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* MESSAGE ID SY-MSGID TYPE SY-MSGTY NUMBER SY-MSGNO
*   WITH SY-MSGV1 SY-MSGV2 SY-MSGV3 SY-MSGV4.
ENDIF.

lo_http->receive(
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1                " Communication Error
    http_invalid_state         = 2                " Invalid state
    http_processing_failed     = 3                " Error when processing method
    OTHERS                     = 4
).
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* MESSAGE ID SY-MSGID TYPE SY-MSGTY NUMBER SY-MSGNO
*   WITH SY-MSGV1 SY-MSGV2 SY-MSGV3 SY-MSGV4.
ENDIF.

*Get the response from target as character string cdata( ).
lv_result = lo_http->response->get_cdata( ).
lo_http->close( ).

We have the response from target system and need to retrieve the data from the string variable lv_result.

 

*Deserialize the data from Json to Abap
/ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(
  EXPORTING
    json             =  lv_result         " JSON string
  CHANGING
    data             =  lr_data           " Data to serialize
).

lt_tab =  VALUE #( ( fielname = 'MATERIALCODE')
                   ( fielname = 'USERNAME')
                   ( fielname = 'MTART'  ) ).

ASSIGN lr_data->* TO <ls_data>.
ASSIGN COMPONENT 'd' OF STRUCTURE <ls_data> TO <ls_d>.

DATA(lo_typedescr) = cl_abap_typedescr=>describe_by_data( <ls_d> ).
ASSIGN <ls_d>->* TO <ls_struct>.
IF <ls_struct> IS ASSIGNED.
  LOOP AT lt_tab INTO DATA(ls_tab).
    ASSIGN COMPONENT ls_tab-fielname OF STRUCTURE <ls_struct> TO <lv_any>.
    IF <lv_any> IS ASSIGNED.
      ASSIGN <lv_any>->* TO <lv_char>.
      IF <lv_char> IS ASSIGNED.
        ASSIGN COMPONENT ls_tab-fielname OF STRUCTURE ls_material TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_target>).
        IF <lv_target> IS ASSIGNED.
          <lv_target> = <lv_char>.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDIF.
UNASSIGN: <ls_data>,<ls_d>,<ls_struct>,<lv_any>,<lv_char>,<lv_target>.

cl_demo_output=>begin_section( 'Material Detail' ).
cl_demo_output=>write_data( ls_material ).
cl_demo_output=>next_section( 'OData Service URL' ).
cl_demo_output=>write_text( lv_url ).
cl_demo_output=>display( ).
CLEAR: ls_material.

The output should be like below in debugger level.

 

Test the above service URI to postman app in GET method.

Note: In the example above, I retrieved data from an OData HTTP API that does not require an SSL certificate. However, when communication with external APIs. an SSL certificate is typically required. We will cover this in detail in a separate blog post.

Thank you!

entry.title: Testing End-to-End Processes Using Sequences
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Cloud ALM now allows the use of so-called test sequences to control the order of test cases and organize them into an orderly sequence. In this article, I will demonstrate how this feature can be used.

Added Value of Sequences

Sequences offer several advantages:

  • A defined order for the sequence of steps/test cases
  • Clearly defined number of test cases per sequence
  • Control of responsibilities
  • Improved preparation and planning
  • Monitoring and tracking of progress

Using Sequences

In Test Plan Management, a sequence can be defined and removed as follows:

Sequence during Test Execution

When executing test cases, users can display the sequence and execute the test cases accordingly:

Conclusion

The sequence function in SAP Cloud ALM is a helpful new feature that creates transparency in the preparation, execution, and evaluation of end-to-end processes and test cases.

Further information on project management and test management:

  • Using test plans in SAP Cloud ALM: LINK
  • Project management with SAP Cloud ALM: LINK
  • Modeling end-to-end business processes: LINK

entry.title: How to add task to an existing transport request using program
entry.content:
PARAMETERS: p_TR TYPE trkorr OBLIGATORY. // Take TR as parameter

 

DATA: lt_authorlist TYPE trwbo_users,

lt_return TYPE e070-trkorr,

ls_return TYPE bapiret2,

lv_new_task TYPE trkorr. // Variable to take task

 

START-OF-SELECTION.

 

 

CALL FUNCTION 'TRINT_INSERT_NEW_COMM'

EXPORTING

wi_kurztext = 'New Task' // Description if creating TR

wi_trfunction = 'S' // 'S' to create task under TR

iv_username = sy-uname // System Username

wi_strkorr = p_TR // Export TR value to FM

IMPORTING

we_trkorr = lv_new_task // Import task to the variable

EXCEPTIONS

no_systemname = 1

no_systemtype = 2

no_authorization = 3

db_access_error = 4

file_access_error = 5

enqueue_error = 6

number_range_full = 7

invalid_input = 8

OTHERS = 9.

IF sy-subrc = 0.

WRITE: / ' New task created under TR:', p_TR,

/ ' Task number:', lv_new_task.

ELSE.

WRITE: / 'Failed to create task. '.

ENDIF.

*********************************************************************************
Type of request/task
Domain : TRFUNCTION
K : Workbench Request
W : Customizing Request
S : Development/Correction
Q : Customizing Task

entry.title: Modern ABAP: Reduce# operator and FOR GROUPS
entry.content:
Business Requirement:

A customer wants to show the sum of GR posted material document & purchase orders(s) net price using the data updated in MSEG & EKPO tables.  For clear understanding breakdown of requirement here,

For each line item of PO should be processed like ERFME (qty) * NETPR (amt) and sum the total amount of line item. 

i.e., 1st line item- 5 * 10.00 = 50.00

      2nd line item- 3 * 100.00 = 300.00

TOTAL = 350.00 

Let's implement this in classic ABAP LOOP...ENDLOOP:

SORT lt_tab BY MBLNR.
LOOP AT lt_tab INTO DATA(ls_data).
  AT NEW mblnr.
    CLEAR lv_netpr.
    APPEND INITIAL LINE TO lt_final REFERENCE INTO DATA(lr_final).
    lr_final->mblnr = ls_data-mblnr.
  ENDAT.
  lv_netpr = lv_netpr + ( ls_data-erfmg * ls_data-netpr ).
  lr_final->netpr = lv_netpr.
ENDLOOP.
FREE lr_final.

The output as follows,

 

Let's achieve this in Modern ABAP using with #FOR GROUPS and #Reduce# operator

lt_final = VALUE #( FOR GROUPS ls_group OF ls_data IN lt_tab
                    GROUP BY( mblnr = ls_data-mblnr )
                    LET lv_total = REDUCE netpr( INIT lv_sum = 0 
                    FOR ls_row IN GROUP ls_group
                    NEXT lv_sum = lv_sum + (   ls_row-netpr * ls_row-erfmg ) )
                    IN
                    VALUE #( mblnr = ls_group-mblnr
                    netpr = lv_total ) ) ).

In debugger Mode,

The GROUP BY clause could be used in classic LOOP...ENDLOOP as well with the field symbol. Kindly refer the blogs that are available in internet.

Thanks for your time!

entry.title: CDS Views Vs Traditional ABAP Logic Performance
entry.content:
Hello Members,

In my previous blog explained how to optimize the classic LOOP....ENDLOOP with modern ABAP syntax FOR GROUPS and REDUCE # operator, please have a look at it if you not seen before.

In this blog we explore how the ABAP CDS (Core Data Service) simplifies the complex logic that used in SAP GUI and boost up the performance of query. 

Below is the code snippet that written in SAP GUI, and the purpose of the code was already explained in previous blog.

SELECT a~mblnr,a~erfmg, a~ebeln, a~ebelp,
       b~netpr
  FROM mseg AS a
  INNER JOIN ekpo AS b ON a~ebeln = b~ebeln
                       AND a~ebelp = b~ebelp
  INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_tab)
  WHERE mblnr IN @s_mbl.

lt_final = VALUE #( FOR GROUPS ls_group OF ls_data IN lt_tab
                    GROUP BY ( mblnr = ls_data-mblnr )
                    LET lv_total = REDUCE netpr( INIT lv_sum = 0
                                                 FOR ls_row IN GROUP ls_group
                                                 NEXT lv_sum = lv_sum + ( ls_row-netpr * ls_row-erfmg ) )
                                                 IN (
                                                 VALUE #(
                                                 mblnr = ls_group-mblnr
                                                 netpr = lv_total ) ) ).

The output of first internal table 'lt_tab' as like,

Output of the second internal table 'lt_final',

Let's simplify the above logic using with ABAP core data services. Pre-requisite, please ensure to use S/4 HANA system, and eclipse with ABAP development tools software.

Here I created two views #Basic and #Composite. The view 'nsdm_v_mseg' has used to fetch the fields from MSEG data instead of database table in Basic view and aggregate function performed in composite view with the required fields in composite view that selected from basic view.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZVIEW_MSEG'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Basic View for MatDoc'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@VDM.viewType: #BASIC
define view ZCAL_MSEG_VIEW
  as select from nsdm_v_mseg as _doc_seg
  association [1..1] to ekpo as _item on  _doc_seg.ebeln = _item.ebeln
                                      and _doc_seg.ebelp = _item.ebelp
{
  key _doc_seg.mblnr,
  key _doc_seg.mjahr,
  key _doc_seg.zeile,
      _doc_seg.ebeln,
      _doc_seg.ebelp,
      _doc_seg.waers,
      @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'meins'
      _doc_seg.erfmg,
      _doc_seg.meins,
      _item.netpr
}

 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Composite View For MatDoc'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@VDM.viewType: #COMPOSITE
define view entity ZCAL_VIEW
  as select from ZCAL_MSEG_VIEW
{
  key mblnr                                                                                      as Material_document,
      ebeln                                                                                      as Purchase_Order,
      @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'Currency'
      sum( netpr )                                                                               as Total_Amount,
      waers                                                                                      as Currency,
      fltp_to_dec( sum( cast(erfmg as abap.fltp) * cast(netpr as abap.fltp) ) as abap.dec(11,2)) as Base_amount

}
where
  ebeln <> ''
group by
  mblnr,
  ebeln,
  waers

The output of the composite view as below,

Let's consume the fields from CDS view in GUI system,

SELECT Material_document, Purchase_order, Total_Amount, Currency, Base_Amount
  FROM zcal_view
  WHERE Material_document IN @s_mbl
  ORDER BY Material_document
  INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_cds_view).

Comparing the internal tables between lt_cds _view and lt_final.

Conclusion:

In traditional GUI based programming data is fetched from database layer and processed in the application layer, whereas the CDS view has pushed down the logic in database layer itself and it is known the Code Pushdown Approach. It makes more efficient than the GUI based approaches, as they reduce data transfer and leverage the power of the database processing.

Based on complexity of your logic you can decide whether go with CDS view or GUI as per the business requirement. But the above logic there is one more way to achieve by select query itself if you are using S/4HANA 7.50.

SELECT a~mblnr, a~ebeln, a~waers,
    CAST( SUM( a~erfmg * b~netpr ) AS DEC( 11,2 ) ) AS total_amt
  FROM mseg AS a
  INNER JOIN ekpo AS b ON a~ebeln = b~ebeln
                       AND a~ebelp = b~ebelp
  WHERE mblnr IN @s_mbl
  GROUP BY a~mblnr, a~ebeln, a~waers
  INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_tab).

Thanks for your time!

entry.title: Include released successor objects from "cloudification repo" in your ABAP custom code migration
entry.content:
Many SAP customers are currently in the phase of migrating their SAP ERP systems to S/4HANA. For those who choose a brownfield or bluefield approach the old ERP system is converted and the customers extensions and own applications (Z* objects) become part of the new system.

Then, the process of Custom Code Adaptation kicks in where the ERP functionality is analyzed and corrected in a way that the objects run again in S/4HANA. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/get-started-with-the-abap-custom-code-migration-process/bc-p/14049622 or https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-system-conversion-custom-code-adaptation-process/ba-p/13337309 for more details.

The custom code correction process can be time consuming and challenging depending on the size and complexity of the original ERP system. A big part of the custom code objects will be touched. The basis for the checks and corrections is the ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) with the check variant for S/4HANA (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023).

In case the customer wants to move functionality to SAP BTP ABAP or the S/4HANA (public) Cloud versions it is not sufficient to make the old ERP code just S/4HANA ready. The cloud versions have a heavily restricted set of the ABAP language (so called language version 5 ) and furthermore access to SAP standard objects is allowed to (relatively few) released objects only. For instance, you must not use the MARA table to read materials but the I_PRODUCT CDS. This information is stored in the so called cloudification repository (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-check-your-custom-code-for-abap-cloud/ba-p/13567124 ) which is regularly updated. (See https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc for the Raw data).

It contains as well successor information for some of the old ERP objects in particular for the data base tables which makes it particularly interesting for the custom code migration process. See note https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3284711 for installation of the according ATC check / check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)"  in releases before 2023 FP 3.

The idea is now to use the officially released successors for the objects which need to be corrected anyway during the migration ERP -> S/4HANA.

A (simple) example: When accessing table SKA1 corrections could be necessary because of the new account type attributes e.g. GLACCOUNT_TYPE in S/4; secondary cost elements are saved now as well. This is found by the S4HANA_READINESS_2023. The same access is found by the "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" check as well:

The solution to solve both issues is to check if secondary cost elements are concerned and to follow the recommendation in the finding. In the correction the successor object (DDLS I_GLACCOUNTINCHARTOFACCOUNTS) should be used directly:

 

This combination approach makes a part of the own developments "cloud ready" and "S/4HANA ready" at the same time without a big additional effort. And anyway, it is better for upgrade stability to use officially released objects!

Here are 3 possible approaches to achieve this:

Approach 1: Out of the box: Combined Check

Create a Z ATC Check variant and select the checks from S4HANA_READINESS* and the check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" . The easiest would be to copy S4HANA_READINESS* and then to select in the maintenance of the check variants (via transaction /nSCI):

 

 

Once you run the check you will see the result as in this example:

 

The findings from the combined check contain already all needed information but there are two shortcomings: the list contains many irrelevant entries; not all check categories (only when the successor is defined) nor all findings are relevant in the context of S/4HANA custom code adoption (e.g. Successor I_COUNTRY for T005 table doesnâ€™t solve a Custom Code Migration issue).

Approach 2: Add information from Cloudification Repo manually

Instead of a combined check variant the successor information could be added via Excel / VLOOKUP (SVERWEIS in German) as well using these steps:

  1. Run the standard ATC check for Custom Code Analysis (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023)
  2. Download the detailed list from ATC to Excel (include in any case the field reference object / Referenzobjekt)
  3. Download the cloudification repo from here https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc/blob/main/src/objectReleaseInfoLatest.csv
  4. Open the data in Excel and copy the sheet to your original excel in a new tab
  5. Add a new column to the first tab from ATC data and combine the data via VLOOKUP: find a possible successor objects in the released objects for the reference objects

A possible result could look like this:

 

I added an example excel for convenience reasons to Github here: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc/blob/main/ATC_S4HANA_CLOUDIF_REPO_EXAMPLE.xlsx 

Then, when processing the ATC findings, the successor objects from Excel can be used directly in the corrections.

Approach 3: Using a custom enhancement to the SAP ATC S/4HANA: Released objects as additional information

In order to avoid the manual Excel steps and to have a lean combined list of the relevant findings only there is also the possibility to enhance the "additional information" section via an implicit enhancement or via another copy of the standard check classes in the S/4HANA Custom Code area. If you decide for the enhancement you can use the methode GET_DETAIL_FROM_DATA_BUFFER  from the central utility class CL_CI_S4H_COMMON and add the successor object information there.

The result is that if there is the successor object available it will be put to the Additional Information Section of the findings as shows the following  example:

 

 

There is an example version on Github for this as well: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc 

Now the existing ATC S4HANA readiness check is enhanced by the new released object information such as that you can directly correct the old ERP object reference and replace it by the latest officially released SAP cloud ready object!

entry.title: ABAP Cloud Sessions at SAP TechEd in 2025
entry.content:
ðŸ”¥ Check out theðŸŸ¢ABAP Cloud sessions at the SAP's Devtoberfest 2025! â€Œâ€ŒðŸ”¥

Hey Everyone!

SAP TechEd in 2025 kicks off on the 4th of November 2025, and preparations are now in full swing at SAP!

SAP TechEd is the leading tech conference for all developers, IT professionals, business experts, tech visionaries, innovators, and leaders eager to gain in-depth knowledge of SAPâ€™s solutions, platforms, and technologies, along with insights into their future direction. It also offer an opportunity to network and connect with peers and SAP experts. 

In 2025, SAP TechEd goes hybrid, kicking off with parallel events in Berlin, Louisville, and online â€“ followed by SAP TechEd on Tour stops in Australia, India, UK, and Germany for a unique opportunity for an in-depth, in-person learning experience. Except for the Berlin and Bangalore stops, the on-site events are organized in partnership with, and hosted by, SAP User Groups and SAPinsider. 

The choice is yours: join us on-site in Berlin or Louisville (at ASUG Tech Connect), or online for the first events in the series! 

Save the date and register now!
ðŸ“…November 4 - 6, 2025
Berlin | Virtual (free of charge) | Louisville

 

ABAP Cloud at SAP TechEd in 2025

ðŸ”§ What to Expect

ABAP continues to evolve, and SAP TechEd events in 2025 are the best place to see whatâ€™s next. Beyond the integration of ABAP Cloud into SAP Build announced last year, and the integration of SAP Joule for Developers into the ABAP development tools along with the ABAP AI SK to infuse AI into your business processes earlier this year,  youâ€™ll have the opportunity to explore the latest innovations and updates in ABAP Cloud, AI-based custom code transformation, clean core practices, and the new clean core levels approach for SAP S/4HANA extensibility in both the private cloud and on-premise.

ðŸ’¡ Why Attending ABAP Sessions Matters

  • Get a clear direction for your ABAP strategy, whether you're on ECC, S/4HANA, or SAP BTP
  • Learn how to modernize custom development without touching the core
  • See how SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities can support faster, cleaner development
  • Take home practical skills for RAP, testing, ABAP Test Cockpit, governance, and more

Access the SAP TechEd 2025 session catalogs:  SAP TechEd Berlin | SAP TechEd Virtual | ASUG Tech Connect. | SAP TechEd Bangalore 2025.

ABAP Cloud Sessions at SAP TechEd Berlin 2025 

ðŸ“… Event Info: 

  • Dates: November 4â€“6, 2025
  • Location: Messe Berlin (Berlin, Germany)
  • Session formats: Strategy talks, roadmap updates, deep dives, community talks, and hands-on workshops
  • 9 Content tracks: ABAP sessions primarily in the tracks "Application Development & Automation (AD)" and "Digital Transformation with Cloud ERP (DT)" 

ðŸŽ¤Keynote

KEY102v | Welcome to SAP TechEd 2025
AI, clean core, data, and agents are changing enterprise tech, but it all comes down to developers. See how SAP is equipping you with the tools, platforms, and learning to turn bold ideas into reality. Experience big announcements, live demos, and a clear view of whatâ€™s next.
Schedule: Tuesday, 4 November 2025 | 8:30 AM - 9:00 AM CET
Speakers: 

  • Muhammad Alam, Executive Board, SAP Product & Engineering, SAP
  • Josh Bentley, Head of SAP Community, SAP
  • Anne Katherine Petteroe, Community Advocate, SAP
  • Nora Von Thenen, Developer Advocate, SAP

KEY100 | Beyond the hype: How SAP is supercharging developers for what's next
Some experts argue thereâ€™s a developer shortage. Others will say developers are no longer needed due to AI. Letâ€™s get real: developers, architects, and technologists are here to stay, and their roles are more important than ever. Explore how the latest technology, tools, AI, agents, and learning from SAP can help you adapt these changing roles. 
Schedule: Tuesday, 4 November 2025 | 4:00 PM â€“ 5:30 PM CET
Speakers:

  • Muhammad Alam, Executive Board, SAP Product & Engineering, SAP
  • Philipp Herzig, Chief Technology Officer, SAP
  • Michael Ameling, President SAP BTP, SAP

KEY101v | Draft day for developers: Turning new technology into real-world wins
The picks are in, and developers, their tools, and frameworks are first-round talent. Get a front-row seat to SAPâ€™s latest innovations built to accelerate how you code, automate, and scale. Explore how you can use SAPâ€™s newest AI capabilities, generative agents, and enhanced tooling to build faster and smarter with less friction and more impact.
Schedule: Wednesday, 5 November 2025 | 9:00 AM - 9:45 AM CET
Speakers: Developer Advocates, SAP

KEY103v | SAP TechEd closing
Wrap up SAP TechEd with highlights, key takeaways, and a look at whatâ€™s ahead. From breakthrough demos to developer wins, celebrate what youâ€™ve learned, where youâ€™ve connected, and how you can keep the momentum going long after SAP TechEd is over. 
Schedule: Thursday, 6 November 2025 | 2:00 PM - 2:30 PM CET
Speakers: Josh Bentley (SAP), Shilpa Shankar (SAP), Laura Schmitz (SAP)

ðŸŽ¯Strategy Talks (25 minutes)

ST109 â€“ SAP Build: ABAP Cloud Strategy | Livestreamed as ST109v at SAP TEchEd Virtual 2025
The ABAP Cloud strategy as part of SAP Build and the SAP strategy go hand-in-hand. Explore in this session what this means for our major topics ABAP AI and Custom Code Transformation and how we integrate Business Data Cloud. Furthermore, learn about the ABAP IDE strategy and how we support the sovereign cloud.
Speakers: Sonja LiÃ©nard (SAP), Boris Gebhardt (SAP)
Schedule: Tuesday, 4 November 2025 |  12:30 PM â€“ 12:55 PM CET

ST113 â€“ Journey to unified extensibility in SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP
Explore the strategy for extensibility across SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP. Learn why AI-driven development with the SAP Build solution including ABAP Cloud is key, and how the planned harmonization will make it easier to build extensions and support the clean core. Furthermore, learn about opportunities for partners to extend SAP solutions.
Speakers: Boris Gebhardt (SAP), Khaled Musilhy (SAP), Lilissa Chao (Exxon Mobil Global Services Co.)
Schedule: Thursday, 6 November 2025 | 9:00 AM - 9:25 AM CET

ðŸ—ºï¸ Roadmap Sessions (25 minutes)

AD808 â€“ SAP Build: ABAP Cloud road map
See our upcoming innovations for the ABAP Cloud development model including Joule and the Business Data Cloud integration in context and get updates on the roadmap ahead.
Speakers: Boris Gebhardt (SAP)
Schedule: Tuesday, 4 November 2025 | 2:45 PM - 3:10 PM CET

DT814 â€“ Extensibility innovations road map for SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP
Explore upcoming extensibility innovations for SAP Business Suite and cloud ERP. Discover road maps for suite extensibility, harmonization, and partner enablement for commercial use cases. Learn more about upcoming innovations for AI-driven extensibility with the SAP Build solution including ABAP Cloud to support your clean core strategy.
Speakers: Oren Shatil (SAP), Boris Gebhardt (SAP)
Schedule: Wednesday, 5 November 2025 | 4:30 PM - 4:55 PM CET

ðŸ”Deep Dives (45 minutes)

AD104 â€“ Boost your  ABAP development with Joule for developers  | Livestreamed as AD104v at SAP TechEd Virtual 2025
In this deep dive session you will learn all aspects of the ABAP AI strategy, from accelerating your ABAP development, over developing custom AI scenarios, up to using Joule to transform your ABAP code.
Speakers: Simona Marincei (SAP), Olga Dolinskaja (SAP)
Schedule: Tuesday, 4 November 2025 | 2:30 PM - 3:15 PM CET

AD105 â€“ Introduction to ABAP Cloud and how to get started 
ABAP Cloud is the new way of developing ABAPâ€”fully cloud-enabled and driven by AI. It combines cloud technologies with a clear separation of SAP and custom code, and in this way revolutionizes ABAP development. Grasp the major concepts of ABAP Cloud and learn how you can upskill. Also learn about Bosch Digitalâ€™s journey to ABAP Cloud and clean core.
Speakers: Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Ajay Kulkarni (Robert Bosch GmbH)
Schedule: Wednesday, 5 November 2025 | 1:15 PM - 2:00 PM CET

AD201 â€“ Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build - what's in for ABAP developers?   
In this deep dive we will highlight the importance of our strategic approach of integrating ABAP Cloud in SAP Build. Learn how you can benefit from this for Fiori App development and how the graphical modeler helps you to create ABAP CDS models conveniently. Finally, get insights into the future direction.
Speakers: Dr. Anne Keller (SAP), Katja Zoch (SAP)
Schedule: Wednesday, 5 November 2025 | 5:15 PM - 6:00 PM CET

DT200 â€“ Unravel the mysteries of Clean Core extensions in Cloud ERP Private 
Learn about the new, enhanced clean core extensibility concept in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Learn about tools like ABAP Test Cockpit and RISE Dashboard, as well as guidance and best practices that help you to measure, govern, re-factor and develop your custom extensions in a clean core compliant, upgrade stable and cloud-ready way.
Speakers: Olga Dolinskaja (SAP), Markus Goebel (SAP)
Schedule: Wednesday, 5 November 2025 | 2:15 PM - 3:00 PM CET

DT201 â€“ Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP
Learn about the on-stack key user and developer tools in the ABAP Cloud development model, now enhanced with generative AI. See how you can extend standard SAP applications and manage your custom apps directly in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Get insights into latest innovations for transactional, analytical, and integration use cases, such as the extensibility AI Assistant, editable tree-views, custom queries for analytical SAP Fiori apps, ABAP SQL services and more.
Speakers: Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Oren Shatil (SAP), Thomas Neuhaus (AGILITA Deutschland GmbH)
Schedule: Tuesday, 4 November 2025 | 2:30 PM - 3:15 PM CET

ðŸ› ï¸ Hands-On Workshops (2 hours)

AD162 â€“ Explore Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities    
Learn how to develop a RAP business object while exploring Joule's ABAP AI capabilities
Speakers: Sebastian Baskovich (SAP), Thomas Alexander Ritter (SAP), Dr. Anne Keller (SAP), Simona Marincei (SAP)
Schedule: Tuesday, 4 November 2025 | 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM CET

AD163 â€“ Fusion Development with ABAP Cloud in SAP Build
In this session we will practice fusion development of ABAP Cloud in SAP Build by creating an ABAP Cloud project from the SAP Build lobby to develop a RAP BO including a Fiori application on top.
Speakers: Ingo BrÃ¤uninger (SAP), Sebastian Baskovich (SAP), Anne Keller (SAP), Katja Zoch (SAP)
Schedule: Thursday, 6 November 2025 | 11:30 AM - 1:30 PM CET

AD164 â€“ Get started with ABAP Cloud for classic ABAP developers    
Familiar with classic ABAP development? Join us to learn how similar development works with ABAP Cloud development model using the ABAP RESTful application programming model (RAP). ABAP Cloud is the comprehensive model for building cloud-ready business apps, services, and extensions that follow clean core principles by default â€“ on SAP BTP and SAP S/4HANA, both in the cloud and on-premise.
Speakers: Volker Drees (SAP), Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Boris Gebhardt (SAP), JÃ¼rgen Reidl (SAP)
Schedule: Thursday, 6 November 2025 | 11:30 AM - 1:30 PM CET

DT260 â€“ Modernize classic extensions to clean core in Cloud ERP Private    
In this session you will practice a clean core extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. You will learn how to govern clean core development using the ABAP Test Cockpit, and how to use ABAP Cloud and clean core extensibility principles to modernize your custom on-stack extensions.
Speakers: Ingo BrÃ¤uninger (SAP), Olga Dolinskaja (SAP), Thomas Fiedler (SAP), Markus Goebel (SAP)
Schedule: Thursday, 6 November 2025 | 9:00 AM - 11:00 AM CET

DT261 â€“ Build on-stack extensions with ABAP Cloud in Cloud ERP Public
Join us to discover how to build extensions, applications, and services with the ABAP Cloud development model, using the ABAP RESTful application programming model and generative AI. You will learn how to extend standard SAP applications, consume public SAP APIs, and build new apps and services from scratch. Get practical insights through exercises and take the opportunity to ask your questions.
Speakers: Ingo BrÃ¤uninger (SAP), Volker Drees (SAP), Steffen Mattes (SAP), Rushikesh Nagle (SAP)
Schedule: Wednesday, 5 November 2025 | 10:30 AM - 12:30 PM CET

DT266 â€“ Troubleshoot and Optimize ABAP Cloud Extensions in Cloud ERP 
Ensuring optimal performance and stability of your ABAP Cloud-based extensions is crucial to long-term success. Learn advanced techniques and best practices for troubleshooting and optimizing custom code in the Cloud ERP. Use powerful tools like ABAP Cross Trace to get deep insights into execution flows and resource consumption.
Speakers: Steffen Mattes (SAP), Juergen Reidl (SAP), Thomas Alexander Ritter (SAP), Thomas Fiedler (SAP)
Schedule: Wednesday, 5 November 2025 | 3:30 PM - 5:30 PM CET

ðŸ‘‹Join Us

I hope this overview gives you even more reasons to join us at one of the SAP TechEd 2025 tour stops in Berlin (DE), Louisville (US), Sydney (AU), Bangalore (IN), Birmingham (UK), or Hamburg (DE) â€“ or attend online, free of charge!

We look forward to meeting and interacting with you! ðŸ¤  In the meantime, you can watch the replays of last year's events: ABAP Cloud at SAP TechEd Virtual 2024 and ABAP Cloud at SAP's Devtoberfest in 2024. You can also have a look at the ðŸ”¥ABAP Cloud sessions at the upcoming Devtoberfest 2025, running online and free of charge from September 29 to October 24, 2025! ðŸ¤

Stay tuned â€“ and see you there!

AD201 â€“ Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build - what's in for ABAP developers?   
In this deep dive we will highlight the importance of our strategic approach of integrating ABAP Cloud in SAP Build. Learn how you can benefit from this for Fiori App development and how the graphical modeler helps you to create ABAP CDS models conveniently. Finally, get insights into the future direction.
Speakers: Dr. Anne Keller (SAP), Katja Zoch (SAP)

DT200 â€“ Unravel the mysteries of Clean Core extensions in Cloud ERP Private 
Learn about the new, enhanced clean core extensibility concept in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Learn about tools like ABAP Test Cockpit and RISE Dashboard, as well as guidance and best practices that help you to measure, govern, re-factor and develop your custom extensions in a clean core compliant, upgrade stable and cloud-ready way.
Speakers: Olga Dolinskaja (SAP), Markus Goebel (SAP)

DT201 â€“ Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP
Learn about the on-stack key user and developer tools in the ABAP Cloud development model, now enhanced with generative AI. See how you can extend standard SAP applications and manage your custom apps directly in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Get insights into latest innovations for transactional, analytical, and integration use cases, such as the extensibility AI Assistant, editable tree-views, custom queries for analytical SAP Fiori apps, ABAP SQL services and more.
Speakers: Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Oren Shatil (SAP)

ðŸ› ï¸ Hands-On Workshops (2 hours)

AD162 â€“ Explore Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities    
Learn how to develop a RAP business object while exploring Joule's ABAP AI capabilities
Speakers: Sebastian Baskovich (SAP), Thomas Alexander Ritter (SAP), Dr. Anne Keller (SAP), Simona Marincei (SAP)

AD163 â€“ Fusion Development with ABAP Cloud in SAP Build
In this session we will practice fusion development of ABAP Cloud in SAP Build by creating an ABAP Cloud project from the SAP Build lobby to develop a RAP BO including a Fiori application on top.
Speakers: Ingo BraÃ¼ninger (SAP), Sebastian Baskovich (SAP), Anne Keller (SAP), Katja Zoch (SAP)

AD164 â€“ Get started with ABAP Cloud for classic ABAP developers    
Familiar with classic ABAP development? Join us to learn how similar development works with ABAP Cloud development model using the ABAP RESTful application programming model (RAP). ABAP Cloud is the comprehensive model for building cloud-ready business apps, services, and extensions that follow clean core principles by default â€“ on SAP BTP and SAP S/4HANA, both in the cloud and on-premise.
Speakers: Volker Drees (SAP), Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Boris Gebhardt (SAP), JÃ¼rgen Reidl (SAP)

DT260 â€“ Modernize classic extensions to clean core in Cloud ERP Private    
In this session you will practice a clean core extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. You will learn how to govern clean core development using the ABAP Test Cockpit, and how to use ABAP Cloud and clean core extensibility principles to modernize your custom on-stack extensions.
Speakers: Ingo BrÃ¤uninger (SAP), Olga Dolinskaja (SAP), Thomas Fiedler (SAP), Markus Goebel (SAP)

DT261 â€“ Build on-stack extensions with ABAP Cloud in Cloud ERP Public
Join us to discover how to build extensions, applications, and services with the ABAP Cloud development model, using the ABAP RESTful application programming model and generative AI. You will learn how to extend standard SAP applications, consume public SAP APIs, and build new apps and services from scratch. Get practical insights through exercises and take the opportunity to ask your questions.
Speakers: Ingo BrÃ¤uninger (SAP), Carine Tchoutouo Djomo (SAP), Volker Drees (SAP), Steffen Mattes (SAP)

DT266 â€“ Troubleshoot and Optimize ABAP Cloud Extensions in Cloud ERP 
Ensuring optimal performance and stability of your ABAP Cloud-based extensions is crucial to long-term success. Learn advanced techniques and best practices for troubleshooting and optimizing custom code in the Cloud ERP. Use powerful tools like ABAP Cross Trace to get deep insights into execution flows and resource consumption.
Speakers: Steffen Mattes (SAP), Juergen Reidl (SAP), Thomas Alexander Ritter (SAP), Thomas Fiedler (SAP)

We look forward to meeting and interacting with you! ðŸ¤  In the meantime, you can watch the replays of last year's events: ABAP Cloud at SAP TechEd Virtual 2024 and ABAP Cloud at SAP's Devtoberfest in 2024. You can also have a look at the ðŸ”¥ABAP Cloud sessions at the upcoming Devtoberfest 2025, running online and free of charge from September 29 to October 24, 2025! ðŸ¤
